Events.RelatedDescription: Closed issue "[NuGet.org Bug]: Intermitient certificate failures" (#10168) at NuGet/NuGetGallery
Events.RelatedBody:
### Impact

I'm unable to use NuGet.org

### Describe the bug

when using NuGet.org I am signing using Azure Trusted Signing the certificate.

I extract the certificate using normal tools, and upload the CER file

The upload validation fails saying there isn't a certificate of the SHA256 found. Even though the certificate uploaded now has a valid name listed against it (which it wasn't previously)
![image](https://github.com/user-attachments/assets/c020a600-19b2-44ba-ac98-42c88f0e2f41)

I check the SHA256 and it matches using the algorithm mentioned (I would provide a screenshot

I am used the cli sign with ATS support, signtool, and jsign

Also NuGet package explorer lists it as a valid certificate 
![image](https://github.com/user-attachments/assets/cdff6d7f-7c15-4c16-9135-c90733ab472f)

I wouldn't be shocked if there is some certificate issue that nuget.org doesn't like and its showing that generic error message?

This used to be a dotnetfoundation owned package (removed the ownership so I can test ATS for the foundation), and DNF has special rules around signing certificate lockouts so not sure if that has something to do with it?

the package name is `Splat`

### Repro Steps

1. Sign a package with ATS
2. Extract the package using certificate extraction tools
3. Upload the CER files
4. Upload the NuGet package.

### Expected Behavior

That when you upload the valid CER file, and have it listed that it 

### Screenshots

_No response_

### Additional Context and logs

_No response_

Events.RelatedDescription: Opened issue "Microsoft.Windows.SDK.NET.Ref was not downloaded" (#10183) at NuGet/NuGetGallery
Events.RelatedBody:
### Impact

I'm unable to use NuGet.org

### Describe the bug

NETSDK1112	The runtime pack for Microsoft.Windows.SDK.NET.Ref was not downloaded. 

### Repro Steps

PM> NuGet\Install-Package Microsoft.Windows.SDK.NET.Ref -Version 10.0.26100.45
Restoring packages for C:\Users\aupingt\OneDrive - Scientific Protein Laboratories\VisualStudio2013Projects\ActiveDirectory\ActiveDirectory\ActiveDirectory.csproj...
  GET https://api.nuget.org/v3-flatcontainer/microsoft.windows.sdk.net.ref/index.json
  OK https://api.nuget.org/v3-flatcontainer/microsoft.windows.sdk.net.ref/index.json 68ms
  GET https://api.nuget.org/v3-flatcontainer/microsoft.windows.sdk.net.ref/10.0.26100.45/microsoft.windows.sdk.net.ref.10.0.26100.45.nupkg
  OK https://api.nuget.org/v3-flatcontainer/microsoft.windows.sdk.net.ref/10.0.26100.45/microsoft.windows.sdk.net.ref.10.0.26100.45.nupkg 842ms
Failed to download package 'Microsoft.Windows.SDK.NET.Ref.10.0.26100.45' from 'https://api.nuget.org/v3-flatcontainer/microsoft.windows.sdk.net.ref/10.0.26100.45/microsoft.windows.sdk.net.ref.10.0.26100.45.nupkg'.
Unable to read data from the transport connection: An existing connection was forcibly closed by the remote host.

### Expected Behavior

When building VS project expect Nuget packages to be restored.

### Screenshots

![image](https://github.com/user-attachments/assets/c90c5ec1-c82e-4404-859c-fe4e8cfea1d3)


### Additional Context and logs

_No response_

Events.RelatedDescription: Merged pull request "[ReleasePrep][2024.09.10]RI of dev into main" (#10176) at NuGet/NuGetGallery
Opened issue "[Localization] Narrator doesn’t read the string “press Alt+Down to navigate any recent search terms” when the focusing is on search-filter of PM UI" (#13790) at NuGet/Home
Events.RelatedBody:
### NuGet Product Used

Visual Studio Package Management UI

### Product Version

Dev\6.12.0.82

### Worked before?

_No response_

### Impact

None

### Repro Steps & Context

#### Details about problem
NuGet Version: Dev\6.12.0.82
VS Version: D17.12\35312.88
OS: Windows-11-Enterprise-23H2 with loc languages pack

#### Installation:
1.	Create a clean VM with loc OS (such as Windows-11-Enterprise-22H2-ZH-TW)
2.	Install VS D17.12\35312.88 from: [Pipelines - Run rel.d17.12-35312.88 (visualstudio.com)](https://devdiv.visualstudio.com/DevDiv/_build/results?buildId=10213565&view=ms.vss-build-web.run-extensions-tab) with loc language pack (such as CHT)

#### Repro Steps: 
1.	Turn on Narrator from ‘Settings->Accessibility->Narrator’ on the VM.
2.	Create a C# Console App (.NET Core 9.0) in VS after setting a loc language (such as CHT) through menu “Tools->Options->Environment->International Settings->Language”.
3.	Go to “Browse” tab and press ‘Tab’ key on the keyboard to focus on the search-filter.
4.	Listen to the reading from Narrator.

#### Expected Result:
Narrator should read the string “press ‘Alt+Down’ to navigate any recent search terms” into loc languages.

#### Actual Result:
Narrator doesn’t read the string “press ‘Alt+Down’ to navigate any recent search terms” into loc languages.
![image](https://github.com/user-attachments/assets/0e7ef85e-f606-4c96-a171-01a81faee731)
#### Notes:   
1.The repro rate is 100%.
2.It reproes on all the local languages: CSY, CHS, CHT, DEU, ESN, FRA, RUS, KOR, ITA, JPN, TRK, PTB, PLK.



### Verbose Logs

_No response_

Events.RelatedDescription: Opened issue "[Localization] There is no semicolon “:” on the right of string “by” for non-recommended package in “Browse” tab of PM UI " (#13789) at NuGet/Home
Events.RelatedBody:
### NuGet Product Used

Visual Studio Package Management UI

### Product Version

NuGet Client Dev\6.11.0.82

### Worked before?

_No response_

### Impact

It bothers me. A fix would be nice

### Repro Steps & Context

**Installation:** 
1. Create a clean VM with loc OS (such as Windows-11-Enterprise-22H2-ZH-CN) 
2. Install VS D17.12\35312.88 from: [Pipelines - Run rel.d17.12-35312.88 (visualstudio.com)](https://devdiv.visualstudio.com/DevDiv/_build/results?buildId=10213565&view=ms.vss-build-web.run-extensions-tab) with loc language pack （such as CHS)

**Repro Steps:** 
1. Create a C# Console App (.NET Core 9.0) in VS after setting a loc language CHS through menu “Tools->Options->Environment->International Settings->Language”.   
2. Right-click the project in Solution Explorer window and select "Manage NuGet Packages…" menu item to open PM UI.   
3. Go to ‘Browse’ tab. 
4. Observe the string “by” on the right of package name in the loaded package list.  

**Expected:**    
The non-recommended package should have a semicolon “:” on the right of string “by” (just like the recommend packages). 

**Actual:**
There is no semicolon “:” on the right of string “by” for non-recommended package. 
![image](https://github.com/user-attachments/assets/a34ec4fb-406d-4ff7-8d94-fd62cc5d4443)


 **Notes:**   
1.The repro rate is 100%. 
2.It just reproes on the local languages: CHS, CHT, JPA, KOR, TRK, PLK. 
3.There is a semicolon “:” for the string “by” in the tooltip of the same package as the screenshot below.
![image](https://github.com/user-attachments/assets/34bfe8f5-af61-4e55-946c-f5528964dc7f)
4. It just reproes in ”Browse” tab, doesn’t repro in ”Installed”/”Updates”/”Consolidate” tab.

### Verbose Logs

_No response_

Events.RelatedDescription: Opened issue "New dependency resolver does not properly handle missing package versions when using CPM" (#13788) at NuGet/Home
Events.RelatedBody:
### NuGet Product Used

dotnet.exe, MSBuild.exe

### Product Version

6.12

### Worked before?

Yes

### Impact

It's more difficult to complete my work

### Repro Steps & Context

If you have two projects where one references the other and you're missing a PackageVersion for CPM, then the new dependency resolver does not handle this correctly.

```
ProjectA -> ProjectB -> PackageX (missing a PackageVersion)
```


During restore of each project, we verify that CPM is configured properly.  For ProjectB, we correctly identify this.  When resolving the graph of ProjectA, none of its package references are missing any versions.  I'm not sure how the legacy dependency resolver handles this.  Maybe it has to do with ordering?

### Verbose Logs

```shell
Directory.Packages.props

<Project>
  <PropertyGroup>
    <ManagePackageVersionsCentrally>true</ManagePackageVersionsCentrally>
  </PropertyGroup>
</Project>


ClassLibrary1.csproj
```xml
<Project Sdk="Microsoft.NET.Sdk">
  <PropertyGroup>
    <TargetFramework>net6.0</TargetFramework>
  </PropertyGroup>
  <ItemGroup>
    <ProjectReference Include="..\ClassLibrary2\ClassLibrary2.csproj" />
  </ItemGroup>
</Project>
```

ClassLibrary2.csproj
```xml
<Project Sdk="Microsoft.NET.Sdk">

  <PropertyGroup>
    <TargetFramework>net6.0</TargetFramework>
  </PropertyGroup>
  <ItemGroup>
    <PackageReference Include="EnvironmentAbstractions" />
  </ItemGroup>
</Project>

```


New resolver output:
```
  ClassLibrary2.csproj : error NU1008: Projects that use central package version management should not define the version on the PackageReference items but on the PackageVersion items: EnvironmentAbstractions.
  ClassLibrary1.csproj : error NU1101: Unable to find package EnvironmentAbstractions. No packages exist with this id in source(s): nuget.org 
```

Legacy resolver output:
```
  ClassLibrary2.csproj : error NU1008: Projects that use central package version management should not define the version on the PackageReference items but on the PackageVersion items: EnvironmentAbstractions.
```
```

Events.RelatedDescription: Opened issue "Apex tests do not call EnsureVisualStudioHost() consistently" (#13786) at NuGet/Home
Events.RelatedBody:
### NuGet Product Used

Other/NA

### Product Version

n/a

### Worked before?

_No response_

### Impact

None

### Repro Steps & Context

This is purely from reviewing the Apex test code and noticing the inconsistency.  Some tests call it, some do not.  It is called often enough that is appears to be used to ensure a consistent state at the start of each test.

A possible fix to ensure this consistency would be to place this call in a [TestInitialize] method on the base test class.  This would by default ensure that all tests follow the same logic, and would simplify test authoring (don't need to remember to copy this every time).

### Verbose Logs

_No response_

Events.RelatedDescription: Opened issue "Consider supporting NoWarn on `PackageVersion` items" (#13785) at NuGet/Home
Events.RelatedBody:
### NuGet Product(s) Involved

NuGet.exe, MSBuild.exe, dotnet.exe

### The Elevator Pitch

It might be easier to suppress a warning on a PackageVersion rather than all PackageReferences when a repo is using CPM.  If this is possible (merely join and append the values) I think it would allow for a better user experience.

### Additional Context and Details

Here's the change which provoked this suggestion: https://github.com/gitextensions/gitextensions/pull/11911

Internal issue: https://devdiv.visualstudio.com/DevDiv/_workitems/edit/1864821
Code in: 

Some ideas: https://github.com/NuGet/NuGet.Client/blob/dev/src/NuGet.Core/NuGet.Protocol/Converters/PackageDependencyGroupConverter.cs

* Avoid using LoadJson, iterate by token.
* Intern the dependency groups /deduplicate
* Ensure GetShortFolderName is not computed continously. The framework parsing tends to be cached, but another ideas to cache that as well.

Events.RelatedDescription: Closed issue "Scream Test Impacting Alpine Linux Customers on 08/20/2024" (#73) at NuGet/Announcements
Events.RelatedBody:
On **August 20, 2024**, NuGet.org will conduct a **scream test** that may affect **Alpine Linux** customers. The test is scheduled to begin at **EDT 01:00 PM** and is expected to last between **24 to 72 hours**. We will adjust the test duration based on customer feedback.

During the scream test, **Alpine Linux** customers may encounter **DNS failures** from the [V3 API](https://learn.microsoft.com/nuget/nuget-org/overview-nuget-org#api-endpoint-for-nugetorg) due to this [issue](https://github.com/NuGet/NuGetGallery/issues/9736). To mitigate, we recommend that Alpine Linux customers migrate to **Alpine Linux 3.18.0** or a newer version. These newer versions support **TCP fallback** in the DNS resolver.

To ensure uninterrupted service during the test, please use the [V2 API](https://learn.microsoft.com/nuget/nuget-org/overview-nuget-org#api-endpoint-for-nugetorg) instead.

If you have any **feedback**, **concerns**, or **questions**, feel free to reach out to us at support@nuget.org or by commenting on the discussion issue: [NuGet/Home#12985](https://github.com/NuGet/Home/discussions/12985).

Events.RelatedDescription: Opened issue "Scream Test Impacting Alpine Linux Customers on 08/20/2024" (#73) at NuGet/Announcements
Events.RelatedBody:
On **August 20, 2024**, NuGet.org will conduct a **scream test** that may affect **Alpine Linux** customers. The test is scheduled to begin at **EDT 01:00 PM** and is expected to last between **24 to 72 hours**. We will adjust the test duration based on customer feedback.

During the scream test, **Alpine Linux** customers may encounter **DNS failures** from the [V3 API](https://learn.microsoft.com/nuget/nuget-org/overview-nuget-org#api-endpoint-for-nugetorg) due to this [issue](https://github.com/NuGet/NuGetGallery/issues/9736). To mitigate, we recommend that Alpine Linux customers migrate to **Alpine Linux 3.18.0** or a newer version. These newer versions support **TCP fallback** in the DNS resolver.

To ensure uninterrupted service during the test, please use the [V2 API](https://learn.microsoft.com/nuget/nuget-org/overview-nuget-org#api-endpoint-for-nugetorg) instead.

If you have any **feedback**, **concerns**, or **questions**, feel free to reach out to us at support@nuget.org or by commenting on the discussion issue: [NuGet/Home#12985](https://github.com/NuGet/Home/discussions/12985).
